questions.question: A 35-year-old man presents with a fever and a rash that started as small, red spots on his trunk and has now progressed to fluid-filled blisters over the past 3 days. He mentions that he recently returned from a business trip where he attended a conference with participants from various countries. What is the most likely period during which he could have contracted chickenpox?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C ) 16 days ago Explanation: In the above scenario, the patient with small, red spots on his trunk and has now progressed to fluid-filled blisters over the past 3 days is most likely to have chicken pox. 16 days ago would mean he had an incubation period of 13 days (16-3), which falls under the incubation period of chicken pox, which is 7-21 days. Epidemiological factors of chicken pox: Agent Varicella-zoster virus (HHV 3- Human Herpes Virus 3) Double-stranded DNAvirus. Source of infection Scabs are not infectious, but the vesicular fluid is infectious. Airborne- spreads via both droplet infection and droplet nuclei Period of communicability 1-2 days before and 4-5 days after the onset of the rash. Secondary attack rate- 85% Host factors Age: <10 years Very common in school-going children One attack gives lifelong immunity Reactivation can occur as Varicella zoster infection in later age Environmental factors More common in winter and early spring The virus can survive outside the body for 24-48 hours. Disinfectants easily kill the virus. Incubation period More common in winter and early spring The virus can survive outside the body for 24-48 hours. Disinfectants easily kill the virus. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pages 161-162

questions.question: Which of the following is transmitted by droplet nuclei?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Chicken pox Explanation: Droplet nuclei, droplet infection, or direct contact transmit chickenpox. Droplet Droplet nuclei Direct mode of transmission Indirect mode of transmission It can spread via contact with the oromucosal membrane, conjunctiva. Enters the alveoli. Heavier particles that are more than 5 microns in size Lighter particles which are less than 5 microns in size They fall on the ground due to gravity They remain suspended in the air, and it can disseminate along with air currents Can travel less than 1 meter in distance (Up to 30-60 cm) Can travel more than 1 meter in distance Examples: Common cold Diphtheria (Option C) Whooping cough Tuberculosis COVID-19 Meningococcal meningitis (Option A) Examples: Tuberculosis Influenza Chickenpox Measles Q fever COVID-19 Mode of transmission of chicken pox: Droplet infection or droplet nuclei Person-to-person contact in the majority of cases Direct contact with vesicular fluid Virus enters through the upper respiratory tract or conjunctiva Can cross the placenta and cause congenital varicella HSV (Option D): spreads via sexual contact Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pages 162, 184, 105, 106 https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/cholera https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK47449/

questions.question: Which of the following statements about chicken pox vaccination is true?

options.A: The chickenpox vaccine is typically administered intravenously.
options.B: Vaccination is recommended only for adults who have never had chicken pox.
options.C: Varicella vaccine effectively prevents chickenpox and its complications.
options.D: Vaccination against chickenpox is only necessary if there is a current outbreak in the community

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Varicella vaccine effectively prevents chickenpox and its complications. severity of the disease if contracted. Immunization against chickenpox: Passive immunization Varicella zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) VZIG is given within 72 hours of exposure and is recommended for the prevention of chickenpox in exposed individuals like: HIV/AIDS or immunocompromised persons Immunosuppressive therapy patients Congenital cellular immunodeficiency Pregnant females Early neonates, premature infants or low birth weights: Given to them if their mother developed chicken pox (given within 5 days before delivery or 48 hours after) Dose: 12.5 units/kg with a maximum of 625 units, repeat the dose in 3 weeks if the high-risk patient remains exposed. Active immunization Vaccine Live vaccine Dose (Option A) 0.5 ml subcutaneous route Schedule (Options B and C) Given in 2 doses, it is recommended for all. If given < 13 years, the duration between two dosages should be 1-3 months For >13 years, the duration between two doses is 4-6 weeks Combination Vaccine Chickenpox vaccine can be given as MMRV– measles mumps rubella varicella. MMRV– administered to 9 months to 12 years of age Two doses schedule with an interval of 4 weeks But it is preferred that 2nd dose be administered 6 weeks to 3 months after 1st dose or at 4-6 years of age. Post Exposure Prophylaxis This can be done if there is known exposure to varicella virus, the vaccine should be given within 5 days of exposure. Pregnancy Vaccine is contraindicated Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 163

questions.question: Which of the following factors was crucial to the successful global eradication of smallpox?

options.A: The causative agent of smallpox, Variola virus, could only survive in humans.
options.B: Smallpox eradication was achieved using a single-dose oral vaccine.
options.C: The Variola virus had multiple animal reservoirs, which made it easier to track and eliminate.
options.D: Smallpox was eradicated because it could be easily diagnosed only with advanced laboratory tests.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) The causative agent of smallpox, Variola virus, could only survive in humans. infected or vaccinated individuals were no longer susceptible and couldn't spread the disease. The smallpox vaccine, administered via a bifurcated needle, was very effective, and its widespread use helped stop its spread. (Option B) The Variola virus, which causes smallpox, had no animal reservoirs, meaning it could only infect humans. Once eliminated from humans, there were no other sources for re-emergence. (Option A and C) Smallpox could be diagnosed based on its distinctive clinical presentation, including a characteristic rash and pustules, without advanced laboratory tests, aiding its eradication. (Option D) Characteristics of Rash: monomorphic , deep-seated, firm, hard vesicles , centrifugal distribution, may become umbilicated , and palms and soles are not spared Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 159.

questions.question: Which of the following is most important to emphasize in educating the public about preventing the spread of diphtheria?

options.A: Diphtheria is primarily spread through contaminated fomites, so good hygiene is crucial.
options.B: Maintaining high vaccination coverage is essential to prevent the spread of diphtheria.
options.C: Individuals who recover from diphtheria are immune to becoming carriers.
options.D: Diphtheria infection primarily affects older adults with weakened immune systems.

questions.explanation: diphtheria. Correct Answer: B) Maintaining high vaccination coverage is essential to prevent the spread of diphtheria. Explanation: Diphtheria outbreaks often occur in areas with low vaccination rates, especially among infants and children. Maintaining high vaccination coverage creates herd immunity, reducing the pool of susceptible individuals and making it more difficult for the disease to spread. Epidemiological Determinant Description Agent Corynebacterium diphtheriae- a Gram-positive, non-motile bacterium that produces a potent exotoxin. Source of Infection Cases (ranging from subclinical to frank cases) Carriers (temporary, chronic, nasal, throat) Nasal carriers pose a higher transmission risk than throat carriers. Period of Communicability Untreated: 14-28 days from disease onset Treated: Cases are non-infectious within 48 hours of treatment initiation. Carriers: Considered non-infectious after two consecutive negative nose and throat cultures taken 24 hours apart Host Factors Age: Primarily affects 1-5 years. (Option D) Sex: Both genders. Immunity: Infants born to immune mothers possess temporary immunity for the first few weeks or months. Mode of Transmission Droplet infection Direct contact with infected cutaneous lesions Contaminated fomites Other Case Fatality Rate (CFR): Up to 10% if left untreated Option A: While contaminated objects (fomites) can contribute to diphtheria transmission, it is not the primary mode of transmission. Droplet infection is the main route of spread. Option C: Recovering from diphtheria does not guarantee immunity from becoming a carrier. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pages 178-180.

questions.question: A 5-year-old child presents with sore throat, low-grade fever, a grayish membrane on the tonsils, and swelling of the neck. Which statement about carriers of this infection is true, and how should they be managed?

options.A: Carriers are asymptomatic and require no treatment.
options.B: Carriers should receive antibiotics to eliminate bacteria and prevent transmission.
options.C: Carriers can be identified by the greyish membrane on their tonsils.
options.D: Carriers are insignificant in disease spread and can be overlooked.

questions.explanation: transmission. Correct Answer: B) Carriers should receive antibiotics to eliminate bacteria and prevent transmission. Explanation: The child’s symptoms indicate diphtheria, an infection caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Carriers of this bacteria, even if asymptomatic, can spread the disease to others. Therefore, it is essential to treat carriers with antibiotics to eliminate the bacteria and prevent further transmission of the disease. Category Description Types of Carriers Healthy carriers: Individuals who carry the bacteria without showing symptoms. Chronic carriers: Carriers harboring the bacteria for an extended period, potentially a year or more. Incubatory carriers: Carriers who are in the early stages of infection and can transmit the bacteria before symptoms appear. Significance Nasal carriers, who shed the bacteria more frequently, are considered more contagious than throat carriers. Diagnosis Two consecutive negative cultures from both the nose and throat, taken 24 hours apart, are required to declare a case or carrier non-infectious. Management of Carriers Oral erythromycin for 10 days. (Option A and B) Important Considerations: Immunization does not prevent the carrier state, meaning immunized individuals can still carry and potentially transmit the bacteria. Option C: Carriers do not exhibit the characteristic symptoms of diphtheria. Option D: Carriers of Corynebacterium diphtheriae are significant in the epidemiology of diphtheria as they can transmit the infection to susceptible individuals. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pages 178-179.

questions.question: A patient presents with suspected diphtheria and has a documented history of severe anaphylaxis to horse serum. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient? administration.

options.A: Administer a full dose of diphtheria antitoxin intravenously, as the benefits outweigh the risks.
options.B: Administer a reduced dose of diphtheria antitoxin intramuscularly with close monitoring.
options.C: Avoid diphtheria antitoxin and treat with high-dose penicillin or erythromycin for 5-6 days.
options.D: Perform skin sensitivity testing with a reduced concentration of diphtheria antitoxin before

questions.explanation: for 5-6 days. Correct Answer: C) Avoid diphtheria antitoxin and treat with high-dose penicillin or erythromycin for 5-6 days. Explanation: The patient in above scenario has a history of anaphylaxis to horse serum and now suspected for diphtheria. The diphtheria anti-toxin consists of horse serum, therefore it is contraindicated in this patient. Feature Diphtheria Antitoxin Type Antisera Preparation Prepared in horse serum Administration Given IM or IV; Skin sensitivity testing should always be performed before administration due to the risk of anaphylaxis from the horse serum. (Option A and B) Dosage 20,000 to 100,000 IU or more, depending on the severity of the case. Indications Treatment of diphtheria; Prophylaxis in non-immunized close contacts. Dosage Examples Mild cases: 20,000-40,000 IU Moderate cases: 40,000-80,000 IU Severe cases: 80,000-1,00,000 IU Anterior nasal diphtheria: 10,000-20,000 units Tonsillar diphtheria: 15,000-25,000 units In addition to diphtheria antitoxin, individuals with diphtheria should also be treated with penicillin or erythromycin for 5-6 days to eliminate C. diphtheriae and reduce toxin production. Option D: Skin sensitivity testing still carries the risk of triggering a severe allergic reaction in a highly sensitized individual. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 180.

questions.question: A child is diagnosed with diphtheria. The child's parent, who is unvaccinated and asymptomatic, is identified as a close contact. What is the MOST appropriate management for the parent?

options.A: Administer a single booster dose of diphtheria toxoid.
options.B: Administer diphtheria antitoxin (DAT) and complete the diphtheria toxoid series.
options.C: Administer prophylactic penicillin or erythromycin only.
options.D: No action is needed since the parent is asymptomatic.

questions.explanation: series. Correct Answer: B) Administer diphtheria antitoxin (DAT) and complete the diphtheria toxoid series. immunity, complete the diphtheria toxoid series for long-term active immunity and prophylactic antibiotics (it is given to all the contacts). Management of diphtheria contacts: Diphtheria Contact Management All Contacts (Option C) Assess for signs and symptoms of diphtheria. Obtain a sample for Corynebacterium diphtheriae culture. Administer prophylactic antibiotics: Penicillin or erythromycin for 7-10 days, stopping if culture results are negative. Unvaccinated close contact (Option B) Administer diphtheria antitoxin (DAT) for immediate passive immunity. Complete the diphtheria toxoid series for long-term active immunity. Unknown vaccination status or received <3 doses Complete the diphtheria toxoid series: This includes 3 primary and 2 booster doses. Received >3 doses, and the last dose was >5 years ago (Option A) Administer a single diphtheria toxoid booster dose Received >3 doses, and the last dose was <5 years ago The contact should receive the next dose of diphtheria toxoid according to the recommended schedule without needing an additional dose due to the current exposure. Option D: Even though the parent is asymptomatic, they are at high risk of developing diphtheria, given their unvaccinated status. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 180.

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman presents with a rash that started as small, itchy red bumps on her trunk and has now progressed to fluid-filled blisters over the past 2 days. She reports feeling generally unwell with a mild fever. What is the most common neurological complication associated with this disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Encephalitis Explanation: This patient with rash that started as small, itchy red bumps on her trunk and has now progressed to fluid-filled blisters over the past 2 days is most likely to have chicken pox. Chickenpox can lead to neurological complications, with encephalitis being the most common. Clinical features of chickenpox: Pre-eruptive stage: Sudden onset Fever, back pain, shivering, malaise Lasts 24 hours (2-3 days in adults) Eruptive stage: Characterized by rash Distribution Symmetrical Occurs on trunk first, then peripheries (centripetal) Mucosal surface involved Palms and soles not involved Rapid evolution Rash evolves from macule to papule to vesicle to scab rapidly Vesicle has a "dew drop on rose petal" appearance Scab occurs 4-7 days after rash appears Pleomorphism All stages of rash (papule, vesicle, scab) are present at once Fever Fever is not high but can spike with each fresh eruption of rash Complications of chickenpox: More likely to occur in immunosuppressed individuals Pneumonia Encephalitis Hemorrhage Disseminated disease in newborn if the mother contracts varicella < 5 days before delivery to 2 days postpartum Reye syndrome, if treated with aspirin Congenital varicella syndrome (if infected in-utero within 20 weeks of pregnancy): Cicatricial skin rash (due to scarring) is the characteristic lesion. Also limb hypoplasia and microcephaly Feature Chickenpox rash Measles rash Type of rash Vesicular rash Maculopapular Lesion Pleomorphic Monomorphic Vesicles Superficial vesicles No vesicles Rash distribution Centripetal Centrifugal Palms and Soles Spared Not spared

questions.question: A pregnant woman is exposed to chickenpox, but her immune status is unknown. According to the guidelines, what is the recommended course of action?

options.A: Immediate administration of the varicella vaccine to prevent maternal infection.
options.B: Test for maternal antibodies to determine immune status.
options.D: Prescription of antiviral medications such as acyclovir to prevent fetal transmission.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Test for maternal antibodies to determine immune status. Explanation: When maternal history of chickenpox is uncertain, she should be tested for IgG antibodies against chickenpox.
